title: 105_s522
content: The "Taxpayer Browsing Protection Act" introduces a penalty for unauthorized inspection of tax returns or tax return information under section 7213A of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Taxpayer Browsing Protection Act" prohibits unauthorized inspection of tax returns or return information by federal employees, state employees, and other individuals. Violations of this law can result in fines upon conviction. The "Taxpayer Browsing Protection Act" prohibits unauthorized inspection of tax returns or return information. Violators may face fines up to $1,000, imprisonment for up to 1 year, or both, along with prosecution costs. Federal officers or employees convicted of violations will also be dismissed from office or employment. Chapter 75 of the Code is amended to include a new item after section 7213. Section 7213A prohibits unauthorized inspection of tax returns or return information. The amendments apply to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. Civil damages are imposed for unauthorized inspection, and notification of unlawful inspection or disclosure is required. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include civil damages for unauthorized inspection or disclosure of taxpayer information. Notification of unlawful inspection or disclosure is required in cases of criminal charges for violations of specific sections. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduce civil damages for unauthorized inspection or disclosure of taxpayer information. The Secretary must promptly notify the taxpayer of any such inspection or disclosure. Exceptions to liability under this section include cases of good faith misinterpretation of section 6103 or inspections requested by the taxpayer. Conforming amendments are made to various subsections of the Code to include "inspection or" before "disclosure" where applicable. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduce civil damages for unauthorized inspection or disclosure of taxpayer information. The amendments include adding "inspection or" before "disclosure" in various sections of the Code to expand the scope of liability. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expand liability for unauthorized inspection or disclosure of taxpayer information by adding "inspection or" before "disclosure" in relevant sections. Effective immediately, the amendments apply to inspections and disclosures after the enactment of this Act. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to reduce the time limit for filing claims from 30 days to 15 days. The amendment is retroactively effective from January 1, 1997, to June 30, 1997.
